text: Hi, I'm new to HubSpot, but at work I need to start a new project with HubSpot and react my question is what is the best project structure for new project HubSpot + React, I already looked at cms-react GitHub repository, but those documentations were written more for professionals than beginners. If someone writes the best practice how to start, I will be very thankful or send some good example because the good start will save hours after.

:wave: Hello <@U077S1KNEKY> - We have a new "Getting Started" example being worked on here <https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-react/pull/62> ... It does a good job with the basics of a project structure.

It's important to understand there are 2 distinct parts of your overall codebase:

1. A HubL "Theme" - in this new getting started example the Theme is very bare bones. For a more robust starting theme for development you can look at the "Boilerplate" <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/building-blocks/themes/HubSpot-cms-boilerplate>
2. A "Developer Project" with a "CMS React" component. In here is where you would build Modules in the CMS React style.
Thanks, <@UAYBXDG4U> for  help, I do not have experience with CMS before, maybe that's why it is so hard for me.
This will walk you through creating a portal, setting up your local development. It doesn’t touch on the React features, but it’s a good foundation.

Yes, I already did it, problem is I used to work with Python and its framework Django as backend and React for frontend and there was easy for me because I can have 100% control of the code, but now I start a new position and they use HubSpot, and I need to create new themes for clients
First day for me was WTF, but now I start to understand what CMS do
Yes - it’s a big adjustment in a CMS because there is the “Content” side of things. A “page” can only be created in the UI and that has to reference a template which then pulls in the dev side
Additionally there is the complexity of modules and fields which give the marketer various powers and control. In a traditional dev stack that layer is not there.

<@U077S1KNEKY> If you know React, I think you'll be ok :raised_hands::skin-tone-2: We're using HubSpot's <https://github.HubSpot.com/cms-react/|cms-react>, and we're able to write 95% or more of our app with React, and have a lot of control over our UI components with our own component library and styling methods. We're only using hubl to create our page templates, and modules that import our React <https://github.HubSpot.com/cms-react/reference/js-partials.html|partials>.

We're connecting to the HubSpot CMS with their <https://github.HubSpot.com/cms-react/reference/js-modules.html#building-fields-with-jsx|JSX fields>, and it's pretty intuitive if you are familiar with React components.
But yeah, learning a new CMS is always a little daunting—just keep going back to the docs, and asking questions here. The HubSpot folks are really helpful and responsive in this channel.
